metadata.case_name: Bijay Cotton Mills Ltd. v. their workmen

facts.text: Respondents claimed scale of minimum wages and rates for contract works as payments by appellant were below bare subsistence wage.
Appellant did not accede to demand for minimum wages.

Dispute referred for adjudication to Industrial Tribunal (Mr. D.N. Roy) on December 1, 1950 under s.10(1) read with s.12(5) of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947. Items: (1) minimum wages and rates for contract works as per statements; (2) dearness allowance Rs.35 per mensem adjustable with prices.
Mr. Roy unable to fix basic minimum wage due to industrial development in Ajmer and price fluctuations; announced award on other items on October 5, 1951.
Respondents challenged Roy's award before Labour Appellate Tribunal.
Labour Appellate Tribunal remanded matter to Mr. Roy on October 20, 1952 to specifically determine basic wage and dearness allowance.
Mr. Roy ceased to be available (no longer District Judge in Ajmer); Mr. Sharma appointed in his place.
Mr. Sharma made award on September 8, 1953 fixing Rs.25 basic wage and Rs.10 minimum dearness allowance.
Sharma's award quashed on May 25, 1955 as appointment not duly published under the Act.

Statutory Committee appointed under Minimum Wages Act, 1948 for Ajmer on January 17, 1952; report submitted October 4, 1952; notification issued October 7, 1952 effective January 8, 1953 fixing basic minimum wage Rs.30 and dearness allowance Rs.26 per mensem.
Mr. C. Jacob appointed Industrial Tribunal on June 17, 1955.

Mr. Jacob made award on January 25, 1956 fixing basic wage Rs.25 and minimum dearness allowance Rs.10 per mensem from December 1, 1950; relied on industry-cum-region basis (Bombay Rs.30, others Rs.22-30, Rajasthan Rs.26, Beawar Rs.25 in 1950), Exhibits 4-A/4-B, 1949 agreement for Rs.27, appellant's 1940 start with 1943 calamity loss of Rs.30 lakhs, workers supplementing from agriculture.
Respondents challenged Jacob's award before Labour Appellate Tribunal (Appeal Nos. 77 and 103 of 1956).
Labour Appellate Tribunal partly allowed appeal on December 12, 1956: increased basic wage to Rs.30 (as per statutory notification), affirmed dearness allowance Rs.10.
Agreement between parties in December 1949 under which respondents willing to work on minimum wage of Rs.27.
Appellant started textile business in 1940, faced calamity in 1943 resulting in loss and liability of nearly Rs.30 lakhs.
Large section of respondents belong to agricultural class and supplement income from agriculture.
Both parties jointly moved Supreme Court in Bijay Cotton Mills Ltd. v. State of Ajmer challenging Minimum Wages Act notification; Court upheld validity.
Mr. Sharma's services not available post-remand as not in State service.
Notification dated December 31, 1954 reappointing Mr. Sharma to correct publication error.
Textile industry included at serial No.23 in First Schedule to Industries (Development and Regulation) Act, 1951.

legal_issues.text: Whether basic minimum wage should be fixed at Rs.25 per mensem (as by Jacob) or increased to Rs.30 per mensem (as by Appellate Tribunal relying on Minimum Wages Act notification).
Whether appointment of Mr. Jacob was invalid as Mr. Sharma's appointment subsisted.
Whether Chief Commissioner of Ajmer competent to refer dispute under s.10(1) r/w s.12(5) of Industrial Disputes Act as textile is controlled industry under Industries (D&R) Act, 1951.

petitioner_arguments.text: Tribunal adopted scientific method of industry-cum-region basis for Rs.25 basic wage; Appellate Tribunal erred in relying on statutory notification for pre-1953 period ignoring that comparable wages included high dearness allowance (e.g. Rs.26 basic + Rs.43 DA); 1949 agreement for Rs.27; company's losses.
Appointment of Mr. Jacob invalid as Mr. Sharma's appointment on Dec 31, 1954 subsisted for same dispute.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: State of Bihar v. D.N. Ganguly Ors. (1959 SCR 1191)

petitioner_arguments.text: Chief Commissioner not appropriate Government as textile industry at Sr. No.23 First Schedule Industries (D&R) Act, 1951 making it controlled industry under s.2(a)(i) Industrial Disputes Act; only Central Government competent.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.2(a)(i) Industrial Disputes Act, 1947; Industries (Development and Regulation) Act, 1951

respondent_arguments.text: Statutory notification under Minimum Wages Act best guide for minimum wage fixation even pre-January 8, 1953 absent satisfactory evidence.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal ignored dearness allowance in comparables making total earnings higher; Appellate Tribunal entitled to rely on statutory notification as useful guide and better than unsatisfactory evidence; no error to apply Rs.30 basic pre-1953 as post-1953 statutory.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Statutory fixation affords best and safest guide.

court_reasoning.text: Sharma's reappointment only to correct publication error; services unavailable post-quashing as not in State service; competent to appoint Jacob to fill vacancy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mr. Sharma's services were not available.

court_reasoning.text: Textile controlled under 1951 Act not enough; requires specific notification by Central Government under s.2(a)(i) Industrial Disputes Act specifying as controlled for that purpose; no such specification.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Specification must be made by Central Government by reference to Industrial Disputes Act.

holdings.text: No interference with Appellate Tribunal's increase of basic wage to Rs.30; no error of law.
Chief Commissioner competent to refer dispute.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bijay Cotton Mills Ltd. v. State of Ajmer
precedents_cited.relevance: Upheld validity of Minimum Wages Act and notification fixing Rs.30 basic wage.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bihar v. D.N. Ganguly Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Petitioner relied on for invalid successive appointments; distinguished as Sharma unavailable.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference of dispute; definition of appropriate Government; requirement of publication of appointment.

statutes_cited.name: Minimum Wages Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Statutory fixation of minimum wages used as guide by Appellate Tribunal.

statutes_cited.name: Industries (Development and Regulation) Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Textile industry scheduled; but no specific specification under Industrial Disputes Act.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave against Labour Appellate Tribunal's decision increasing basic minimum wage to Rs.30 per mensem dismissed; upheld wage fixation, Jacob's appointment, and reference validity. No interference under Art.136.

key_quotes.text: "the statutory notification issued under the Minimum Wages Act affords the best and safest guide in the matter of fixation of minimum wage."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Basis for upholding Rs.30 basic wage even pre-1953.

key_quotes.text: "in ascertaining the wages which labour in comparable trades was getting in the relevant region, the tribunal has completely lost sight of the fact that in addition to the basic wages of Rs.26/- Rs.43/- was the average minimum dearness allowance"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Critique of lower tribunal's industry-cum-region method.

key_quotes.text: "the specification must be made by the Central Government by reference to, and for the purpose of, the provisions of the Act"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies requirement for Central Government as appropriate authority.
